title-group.article-title: Correlational nutritional relationships and interactions between expansive holoparasite Orobanche laxissima and woody hosts on metal-rich soils

kwd.tp:taxon-name: O. lucorum A. Braun ex F.W. Schultz

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Correlational nutritional relationships and interactions between expansive holoparasite
Orobanche laxissima
and woody hosts on metal-rich soils
Renata Piwowarczyk a , Ireneusz Ochmian b, * , Sabina Lachowicz c , Ireneusz Kapusta d , Katarzyna Malinowska e , Karolina Ruraz ˙a
a Center for Research and Conservation of Biodiversity, Department of Enviromental Biology, Institute of Biology, Jan Kochanowski University, Uniwersytecka 7 Street, PL-25-406, Kielce, Poland

b Department of Horticulture, West Pomeranian University of Technology Szczecin, S ł
owackiego 17 Street, 71-434, Szczecin, Poland

c Department of Fermentation and Cereals Technology, Wroc ł aw University of Environmental and Life Sciences, Che ł mo´nskiego
37 Street, 51-630, Wroc ł
aw, Poland

d Department of Food Technology and Human Nutrition, University of Rzesz´ow , Zelwerowicza 4 Street, 35-601,
Rzesz´ow, Poland

e Department of Bioengineering, West Pomeranian University of Technology Szczecin, S ł
owackiego 17 Street, 71-434, Szczecin, Poland
ARTICLE INFO

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Broomrape
Host
Soil–host–parasite transfer Environmental stress
Metal accumulation
Metal relocation Polyphenols Phenylethanoid glycosides
ABSTRACT

Plant parasitism by other plants, combined with abiotic environmental stress, offers a unique opportunity to study correlational nutritional relationships in terms of parasite–host interactions and their functional roles in nutrient cycling in ecosystems. Our study analysed the transfer of selected mineral elements, including heavy metals, from soil to different organs in hosts (
Punica granatum
and
Fraxinus angustifolia
) and from hosts to the expansive holoparasite (
Orobanche laxissima
) in cinnamonic soil habitats in Georgia (Caucasus). We also identified other correlated trophic and bioactive effects in the parasite–host relationship.
O. laxissima
was characterized by a high accumulation tendency for micro- and macroelements, such as K and Ca, and heavy metals, such as Zn, Ni, and Cd. Parasites can reduce the concentration of heavy metals in host tissues owing to this high accumulation tendency. In total, 85 compounds were identified in the examined parasite and its hosts. Despite the distinct phytochemical content of species of the infected host, the parasite produced specific metabolites with dominant phenylethanoid glycosides (PhGs), with acteoside and crenatoside being the primary dominant compounds - ca. 98% of all polyphenols. Polyphenols in parasite specimens that are correlated with Cu and Zn are antagonistic to polyphenols correlated with Fe, Pb, Cr, and Ni. The profile of polyphenols in the host species was both qualitatively and quantitatively distinct from the profile of the compounds in the parasite and between hosts (only acteoside in group PhGs was common between the parasite and
Fraxinus
host), which indicates the existence of a unique compound biosynthesis pathway in the parasite. Our results demonstrated that the parasite, particularly in its flowers, exhibited higher polyphenol content, antioxidative effects (ABTS-+, DPPH, and FRAP), and inhibitory effects.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
In this study, we used
Orobanche laxissima Uhlich
& R¨atzel ( Orobanchaceae ) as a parasite on two hosts from distinct families,
Punica granatum
L. ( Lythraceae ) and
Fraxinus angustifolia Vahl (Oleaceae)
.
O. laxissima
appears to be polyphagous (infecting many unrelated host species) as the most expansive holoparasite species of the roots of trees in the Caucasus (Western Asia). It has been listed from the natural or seminatural forest and shrub habitats. However, our recent observations in horticulture and arboriculture suggest an important economic influence since it may spread to adjacent forest communities and cultivated areas and it has the potential to easily adapt to many different host trees. This is particularly notable because parasite populations can produce several thousand shoots (
, 2021) and indirectly affect local ecosystems.
Orobanche
s.l. species have rarely been observed to parasitize the roots of trees or shrubs. Only a few other species in the genus are reported to do so; for example,
O. lucorum A. Braun ex F.W. Schultz
is known to parasitize
Berberis
L. and rarely
Crataegus
L., while
Phelipanche libanotica (Schweinf. ex Boiss.)
Soj´ak has been found to parasitize
Prunus
L. (S´anchez
;
).

To date, the chemical and mineral composition of
O. laxissima
has not been evaluated, and our study opens doors for its exploitation as a functional food and pharmacologic and therapeutic agent; moreover, this analysis elucidates the influence of host and contaminated soils on harvested parasitic herbs. We examined two localities, both in wooded communities, within the range of cinnamonic soils (fertile clay soils rich in humus) in Georgia (Caucasus) exhibiting significant concentrations of toxic metals in the soil. The objectives of our study were to (I) determine the accumulation and translocation of micro- and macroelements with toxic metals from soil to particular plant organs (in both the hosts and the parasite); (II) evaluate the nutritional value, phytochemical composition, and bioactivity of
O. laxissima
by comparing particular organs and of
P. granatum
and
F. angustifolia
by evaluating various organs in plants from different localities; (III) determine whether the compounds identified were synthesized by holoparasites or obtained from their host plants; (IV) determine whether the host species affects the qualitative and quantitative composition of parasitic polyphenols and bioactivity; and (V) evaluate the function of holoparasites in wooded ecosystems as keystone species, highlighting their potential effects on nutrient cycling.

sec.title: 2.1. Macro-, microelements and heavy metals content
sec.p:
Punica granatum
and
Fraxinus angustifolia
with
Orobanche laxissima
parasitizing their root systems were grown in fertile humus-rich loamy cinnamonic soils. These soils were characterized by neutral pH and low

The content of macroelements and heavy metals in the soil has a direct influence on plant uptake. Individual species have physiologically determined needs for macro- and microelements, but in general, they take up them in proportion to their soil content. Higher elemental content in the soil did not generally lead to higher uptake by the host.
P. granatum
leaves exhibited lower concentrations of Mg, Ca, K, Cu, Cr, Ni, and Zn than the leaves of
F. angustifolia
( Table 3 ). However,
O. laxissima
accumulated more K, Ca, Fe, and toxic Cr, Co, Cd, Pb, and Ni when parasitizing
P. granatum
than when parasitizing
F. angustifolia
( Table 3 ). We also found that flowers of
O. laxissima ,
regardless of host species, accumulated more Mg, Ca, Ni, and Zn and less Co and Fe than the stems of this species ( Table 3 , Fig. 1 ). The indicator organs of the parasites were characterized by a minimal ability to uptake Ca from the hosts. In the leaves of
F. angustifolia, Ca
was 14.49 g / 1000 g , but in the stem of
O. laxissima
parasitizing it, the concentration was more than ten times lower ( 1.37 g / 1000 g ).

The bioaccumulation of metals in the examined parasite largely depended on the host species and organs.
O. laxissima
is characterized by a high microelement and heavy metal accumulation tendency. The flowers and stems of
O. laxissima
strongly accumulated Cr in relation to the
P. granatum
host (bioaccumulation factor > 10) and Fe, Cd, and Ni, as well as Pb and Zn (bioaccumulation factor 1–10). However,
O. laxissima
parasitizing
F. angustifolia
accumulated Ni, Zn, Cu, and Fe in its flowers ( Fig. 2 ).

Additionally, our results also indicate an interesting relationship between the content of some elements in the soil–host–parasite ecological community, specifically considering the potential for human involvement in this system. The circulation of toxic heavy metals is particularly important. Holoparasites from the Orobanchaceae are widely used in herbal medicine, and the proven bioaccumulation capacity of some heavy metals requires better scientific recognition. Cu was present in both host and parasite specimens in amounts up to 12.4 mg / 1000 g . The uptake of Cu by the host was not related to the soil concentration. In contrast, Cu uptake by
O. laxissima
was proportional to the content in the host. The flowers of
O. laxissima
parasitizing
Fraxinus
exhibited Cu accumulation ( 11.62 mg / 1000 g ). Cu levels exceeding 20 mg / 1000 g in food products are toxic to humans. However, Cu deficiency in humans is more unfavourable than excessive consumption, as it disturbs many biological processes (
). The RDA of Cu, according to the Age-Related
and
, is 0.7–0.9 mg , and the upper limit is 10 mg (
). The soils from Antoki were significantly richer in Zn than those from Sighnaghi. This was translated into a significantly higher uptake of this element by the host
Fraxinus
and the
Orobanche
parasitizing it. The highest Zn concentration was found in the flowers of
O. laxissima
(up to 45.84 mg / 1000 g ). In contrast, the content in the stem was significantly lower than that in the host. There are no standards defining the acceptable level of Zn in food products. It is considered necessary in low amounts for the proper functioning of living organisms. The daily human requirement for zinc is 15–20 mg (
). According to
, it would be unwise to exceed a daily intake of 30 mg in adults. Ni is a toxic element with a high accumulation factor in
Orobanche
. Found its high concentration in the analysed parts of hosts (3.01–4.06) and the parasite ( 4.05–4.99 mg / 1000 g ). The average Ni content in fresh foods is 0.079 mg / 1000 g (
) and should not exceed 0.5 mg / 1000 g (GB 2762–2012). Population exposure to nickel from food has decreased since 1976 ( 0.33 mg /day), and it has been relatively stable since 1982– 0.13 mg /day in the 2006 TDS (
). Notably, high levels of this element indicate that consuming a small amount of stem of
O. laxissima
may pose a threat to human health. Despite the low level of Cr in the leaves of
P. granatum
( 0.06 mg / 1000 g ), the Cr content in the stem of the parasite reached 1.09 mg / 1000 mg . The translocation factor, which is the ratio between the metal content of the plant and the soil, is calculated to determine the degree of bioaccumulation. In this case, the bioaccumulation index was 18.1. In the
Orobanche laxissima
flowers (Sighnaghi, parasite on
P. granatum
), Cr was at an even higher level of 1.64 mg (bioaccumulation index 27.3). In fresh vegetables and fruit of other species, the average Cr level has been reported to be
0.007 –0.008 mg
/ 1000 g (
). The daily requirement of an adult human for Cr is 0.2 mg /day (
). The host plants and flowers of the parasite contained a typical Cd amount for most plants ( 0.2 mg / 1000 g ). However, in the stem of the parasite, the amounts of Cd were approximately tenfold higher at 1.85 and 2.53 mg / 1000 g when parasitizing
Fraxinus
and
Punica
hosts, respectively. For plants, the toxic amounts of Cd range > 3 mg / 1000 g (
); however, in food products, they should not exceed 0.2 mg / 1000 g (Journal of Laws 37/326). Humans should not consume more than 0.007 mg /kg body weight - weekly dose. Plants take up Co in proportion to their content in the soil (
). The leaves of
P. granatum
contained most of the Co ( 0.41 mg / 1000 g ). Tested
O. laxissima
also contained small amounts of Co regardless of host species, up to 0.36 mg / 1000 g . These amounts are much smaller than those in fruits, vegetables, and grains (
). Cobalt is an essential element for animal organisms. Humans consume an average of 0.04–0.05 mg Co a day, and its absorption is 50%. One-time consumption of high concentrations of Co ( 25–30 mg ) is toxic to humans (
). The host plants contained traces of Pb ( 0.01 mg / 1000 g ). A very low level of Pb was also
*Mean values denoted by the same letter between locations do not differ statistically significantly at 0.05 according to Tukey’ s test.
a See Table 1.
* Mean values denoted by the same letter in the horizontal line do not differ statistically significantly at 0.05 according to Tukey’ s test.

observed in
O. laxissima
parasitizing
Fraxinus
. Conversely,
O. laxissima
parasitizing
Punica
accumulated Pb to a level of 0.24 mg / 1000 g . In the flowers of
O. laxissima
parasitizing
P. granatum
and in the stems of that parasitizing
F. angustifolia , Pb
was also observed with a bioconcentration factor > 1. Despite significant accumulation, total amounts were low and remained safe for human consumption (up to 0.3 mg / 1000 g ).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: a See Table 3. b nd. - not detected.

sec.title: 2.2. Polyphenol content
sec.p:
The results showed that the content of polyphenolic compounds in the parasite specimens were dependent upon on the type of host and morphological parts ( Table 4 ). Thus, the content of the polyphenolic compounds in parasite on
P. granatum
host was 1.5 times lower than in parasite on
F. angustifolia
host. The average amount of bioactive compounds in the
P. granatum
host was 1.3 times higher than in the
F. angustifolia
host. Such differences can be due to the content of the polyphenolic compounds identified on the host plant. The parasite, irrespective of the host, was dominated by PhGs, particularly acteoside. It was at a higher level in flowers (3273 and 5095 mg / 100 g ) than in stems (2105 and 3781 mg / 100 g ). Similar relationships were found in several parasites collected in Poland . They were also dominated by acteoside (
). Similar observations were reported for
Cistanche armena
parasitizing two host species (
Alhagi maurorum Medik.
and
Salsola dendroides Pall.
) (
). According to
, the concentration of polyphenols in the
Orobanche foetida Poir.
to
O. crenata
was between 3.02 and 19.99 mg GAE/g dry weight (DW), while the average amount of bioactive compounds in the
C. armena
parasite was 920 mg / 100 g DW (
). Moreover, the average amount of analysed compounds in
O. laxissima
was 1.4 times higher in the flowers than in the stem. The stem of
O. laxissima
were richer in polyphenols and contained around 3.4 and 1.2 times more than the flowers of
C. armena
parasitizing
S. dendroides
and
A. maurorum
, respectively (
). The bioactive compound diversity among morphological parts was observed in
Cistanche phelypaea
(L.) Cout.; the authors noted that the dominant metabolites observed in the flowers were glycoside and bartsioside, that in the stems was primarily acteoside, and those in the roots were echinacoside and tubuloside A (
). Among the identified compounds, PhGs (mainly acteoside and crenatoside) were dominant compounds and accounted for 97.8% of all polyphenols on average. Moreover, flavonols (2%), and phenolic acid (0.2%) were the predominant observed flavonoids. According to
, PhGs were predominantly identified in the parasite of
C. armena
.
O. laxissima
parasitizing
F. angustifolia
contained 1.5 times more phenylethanoid glucosides then that parasitizing
P. granatum
. The amount of flavonols and phenolic acids was highest in the
O. laxissima
parasitizing
P. granatum
. One exception to the accumulation trends observed is the acid identified only in the flowers of parasite on
P. granatum
host, while no acid was identified in the host itself. PhGs substances are abundant in medical plants as well as traditional Chinese medicines, and they exhibit anti-inflammatory, neuroprotective, antibacterial, antioxidant, antivirus, cytotoxic, and immunomodulatory characteristics (
).

Tables S 1–3
in the Supplementary Materials and Fig. 4 show the results for the flowers and leaves of
P. granatum
and fruits and leaves of
F. angustifolia
, which exhibited different profiles of polyphenolic compounds. This indicates a unique biosynthesis pathway for polyphenols. Acteoside is the only compound present in the parasite and host
F. angustifolia
, and this compound was likely not taken up from the host by the parasite because acteoside is present in both species (
). The host actoside content was significantly lower (221 and 415 mg / 100 g ) than that of the parasite ( 2105–5095 mg / 100 g ). The results of colour analysis of the tested species suggest that host plants may influence the colour of indicator elements of the parasite and are presented in the Supplementary Materials ( Table S4 ).

However, the predominant compounds in the flowers of the
P. granatum
host were hydrolysable tannins (accounting for 95% of all polyphenols), with flavonoids accounting for 5%, while hydrolysable tannins in the leaves accounted for 100%. In the fruits and leaves of the
F. angustifolia
host, the major compounds include phenylethanoid glucosides and flavonols, which accounted for 38% and 34% of all compounds, respectively. The content of polyphenols in the flowers of both hosts was similar, whereas in the leaves of the
P. granatum
host, the amount of polyphenols was 2 times higher than that in the leaves of the
F. angustifolia
host ( Fig. 3 ). This difference was observed due to the specificity of the tested hosts in synthesizing different amounts of polyphenols (
;
; Fale´et al., 2013). According to
, the polyphenol content in the flowers of
P. granatum
was 944.75 mg GA/g DW and was 1.7 times lower in the flowers of the parasite. In turn,
P. granatum
peel in the study by
, 2011b) contained 6.4 and 5.3 times more polyphenols than in the flowers and leaves of the
P. granatum
host. Recent data have presented some evidence for the sequestration of metabolites, such as alkaloids, flavonoids, and iridoid glycosides, by some hemi- and holoparasites from their host species (
;
).
a See Table 3.

sec.title: 2.3. Determination of enzyme inhibition potency and antioxidant activity
sec.p:
The results show distinct, host-dependent antioxidant and diabetic properties among the tested parts of
O. laxissima
. The flowers of the parasite were characterized by significantly higher inhibitory activities than those of the stem ( Table 5 ). A similar relationship was found in the
Phelypaea tournefortii
parasite (
), contrasting the finding in the
Cistanche armena
study (
). The flowers were also characterized by higher antioxidative effects determined by ABTS-+, DPPH, and FRAP. The greatest differences were found in the DPPH method results. The flowers were characterized by antioxidative compounds that were twice as abundant as those in the stem. Other studies have also shown that parasite flowers exhibit a greater ability to chelate and reduce Fe (
). Antioxidative effects may be influenced by the host species, as confirmed by the results obtained for
C. armena ( Piwowarczyk et al., 2020a )
and
C. violacea ( Debouba et al., 2012 )
.

A significant difference was found in the nitrate content, particularly in the indicator parts of the parasite in comparison with the hosts. The host leaves contained a nitrate concentration that was approximately seven times higher than that of the parasite stem ( Table 5 ). The stem of another parasite,
P. tournefortii ( Piwowarczyk et al., 2020b )
, had a significantly lower nitrate content. The low concentration of nitrates in the parasite may be indicative of their intensive growth, rapid nitrate reduction, and rapid tissue development. The fast growth rate may also contribute to the increased uptake of other components, including heavy metals.

sec.title: 3. Conclusions
4.1.1. Species studied
sec.p:
For this study, we selected the holoparasite
Orobanche laxissima
R¨atzel & Uhlich ( Orobanchaceae ) and two of its hosts,
Punica granatum
L. ( Lythraceae ) and
Fraxinus angustifolia Vahl (Oleaceae)
( Fig. 5 ).

O. laxissima
is an expansive polyphagous root holoparasite that infects many wild and sometimes cultivated trees and shrubs from families such as Betulaceae , Oleaceae , Aceraceae , and Fagaceae , including
Fraxinus
L.,
Fagus
L., and
Carpinus
L. species (
). Moreover, recent reports have indicated the potential parasitism of economically significant forest and fruit tree plantations, such as those of
P. granatum
(
, 2021). This organism has been identified in the Caucasus Mountains and Transcaucasia, particularly in Russia , Georgia , Armenia , Azerbaijan , and NE Turkey (
). This parasitic plant flowers from May to July and develops fruits from July to August.
O. laxissima
prefers moist, shady, or semi-shady areas in deciduous forests, particularly hornbeam-oak, hornbeam-beech, roadsides on the edge of the woods and roads, scrubs, and in submontane and montane zones ~ 200–2000 m . It spreads in mountain and foothill forests, shrubs, and plantations of the Caucasus, appearing very numerous, with as many as thousands of individual population sizes.

The first host,
P. granatum
, commonly known as pomegranate, is native to the Caucasus, the Himalayas in North Pakistan , and Northern India and is widely cultivated, although it often grows wild. Pomegranate is one of the first domesticated fruits and has been used in folk medicine and as a food for centuries. The plant’ s fruit, seeds, leaves, flowers, roots, and bark extracts exhibit extensive medicinal properties (
).
P. granatum
has been naturalized in some areas in Georgia , appertaining to relict species, which typically occur on slopes and plane regions with grey-cinnamonic and cinnamonic soils (
).

The second host,
F. angustifolia
, is native to central and southern Europe, northwest Africa, and southwest Asia.
F. angustifolia
occurs mainly in the lowlands in riparian and floodplain forests along large rivers, where it forms vast and continuous populations; rarely, it creates pure stands that are found only in optimum conditions as a pioneer species at higher altitudes. Usually, this ash is a dominant or a secondary species in mixed broad-leaved forests, forming stable and species-rich ecosystems. Parts of the plant are harvested for wood, food, and ornamental uses, and it has been reported to exhibit antioxidant, anti-

sec.title: 4.1.2. Study site and general habitat structure
sec.p:
The study was conducted in
May 2019
in two localities in the Caucasus Mountains of southeast ( Kakheti province ) Georgia ( Western Asia ):

1. Sighnaghi, in direction to Tsnori, in roadside and hill scrub with wild and cultivated areas of
P. granatum
,
41 ◦ 37,375 ′ N
,
45 ◦ 56,303 ′ E
, 480 m a.s.l. The parasite population consisted of at least a ca. a thousand shoots, sometimes in one clump was ca. 100 individuals. A single pomegranate plant was parasitized by a few to hundred broomrape plants, and 10–20% of the ca. 1 ha location was infested.

2. Antoki near Sagarejo,
F. angustifolia
cultivation near the road, at the foot of the Greater Caucasus range, in the vicinity of Caucasian mixed hornbeam-oak forests,
41 ◦ 43 ′ 15,2 ′′ N
,
45 ◦ 22 ′ 19,7E
", 755 m a.s.l. The population of the parasite consisted of at least 2000 shoots. A single plant of ash was parasitized by several to 100 broomrape plants, and 30–40% of the approximately 1-ha location was infested.

sec.title: 4.2.1. Soil
sec.p: Samples were collected with a soil rod with a diameter of 40 mm . They were used to prepare a pooled sample. The estimation of the content of minerals in dry weight plants and soil was carried out in accordance with the Polish standard using certified reagents. All tests were performed in three replications.

sec.title: 4.2.2. Plants
sec.p:
Samples, separately, flowers and stems (inflorescence stalk – aboveground part of the stem, with tuber – underground part of the stem) of the parasite
O. laxissima
were collected using a shovel and washed. Samples of the host species
P. granatum
(leaves and flowers, separately) and
F. angustifolia
(leaves and fruits, separately) infected by the parasite were collected from the aforementioned localities. Following harvesting under natural conditions, the materials were dried. Voucher specimens were deposited in the Herbarium (KTC) of Jan Kochanowski University in Kielce. The plant names were updated based on the International Plant Names Index (IPNI, 2020), the most recent data according to
and the Index of Orobanchaceae (S´anchez
).

sec.title: 4.2.3. Elemental analysis
sec.p: 4.2.3.1. Soil. Soil samples were collected to determine the macroelement and toxic metal concentrations in the soil. The samples were
collected in the rhizosphere zone of the attachments of the parasite with hosts, ca. 25 cm .

The pH of the soil in KCl and salinity were measured potentiometrically by the ELMETRON CX 742 instrument. The estimation of the content of minerals in dry weight was carried out in accordance with the Polish standard (PN) using certified reagents.

The contents of total forms in soil macro-, microelements and heavy metals were determined after mineralization in HNO 3 and HClO 4 at a ratio of soil 1:1 (Polish Standard PN-R-04016-21, 1992). In the soil, available K and P were determined by extraction in C 6 H 10 CaO 6, and Ca and Mg were determined by extraction in C 2 H 3 O 2 NH 4 . The contents of K and Ca were measured with atomic emission spectrometry, whereas the Mg content was measured with flame atomic absorption spectroscopy using an iCE 3000 Series. The P content was determined with the Barton method at a wavelength of 470 nm , employing a Marcel s 330 PRO spectrophotometer.

The contents of available micronutrients (Cu, Zn, Fe) and heavy metals (Pb, Cr, Cb, Cd, Ni) were extracted in 1 mol HCl and measured with flame atomic absorption spectroscopy using an iCE 3000 Series with Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrometry air/acetylene (
). Assessments of the accuracy and precision of the analytical methods and procedures used were determined using certified reference material: CRM036–050 Loamy Sand 4 (CRM 036–050 produced by Resource Technology Corporation, USA and UK ). The effectiveness of the process was validated with 90–95% efficiency. The results shown are the average of three measurements, working standards made from Merck standards with a concentration of 1000 mg /dm3. The limits of detection were as follows (mg/kg): Ca 0.004; Mg 0.002; K 0.001; Na 0.004; Fe 0.004; Cd 0.003; Co 0.010; Cu 0.005; Ni 0.008; Pb 0.013; Zn 0.003 and Mn 0.002. Tests were performed in three replications.

4.2.3.2. Plants. The contents of elements in plants were determined after mineralization: Mg, P, K and Ca were measured after wet mineralization in H 2 SO 4 and HClO 4 . The contents of Cu, Pb, Cr, Ni, Cb, Cd, Zn and Fe were determined after mineralization in HNO 3 and HClO 4 at a ratio of plants of 3:1 (IUNG, 1990). The K content was measured with atomic emission spectrometry, and the Mg Ca, Cu, Pb, Cr, Ni, Cb, Cd, Zn and Fe contents were measured with flame atomic absorption spectroscopy (iCE 3000 Series). The efficiency of the process was validated with 90–95% success using certified reference materials, namely, tea leaves (INCT-TL-1) and a mixture of Polish herbs (INCT-MPH-2), both produced by the Institute of Nuclear Chemistry and Technology, Warsaw, Poland , which was assessed by the colourimetric method. All tests were performed in three replications.

sec.title: 4.3.1. Antioxidant effect and inhibitory activity
sec.p:
Extraction of a compound mixture of organs (flowers, stems, fruits, leaves, separately) from the parasite and hosts was performed using 70% ethanol at 20 ◦ C for 60 min with constant stirring. Following centrifugation at 4000 rpm for 10 min, the supernatant was filtered under reduced pressure through a cellulose membrane with a 1.2 μm pore diameter, and the supernatant was concentrated at 40 ◦ C in a vacuum evaporator to remove acetone. Subsequently, the aqueous phase was diluted with water. The plant extract was serially diluted using redistilled water to obtain a gradient of concentrations for use in analytical and biological activity assays (
).

sec.title: 4.3.2. Polyphenols
sec.p:
The flowers and stems from the parasite and flowers, fruits and leaves from the hosts were extracted as described by
. All extractions were performed in triplicate.

sec.title: 4.4. Health promoting capacities
4.5. Analysis of polyphenolic compounds using the UPLC-PDA-ESI-MS/
sec.p: MS method

Polyphenolic compounds were analysed using a UPLC-PDA-ESI-MS/ MS Waters ACQUITY system (Waters, Milford, MA, USA ) as method described by
for polyphenolic compounds, a lower concentration of formic acid was used (0.1% v/v). The program was set as follows: 0 min 5% B; 0–8 min, linear to 100% B; 8–9.5 min, washing, and back to initial condition. The sample injection volume was 5 μl. The polyphenolic compound detection and identification were based on the specific PDA spectra, mass to charge ratio, and fragment ions obtained following collision-induced dissociation (CID). Additional settings are enlisted in
Table 1
in Appendix. Quantification was achieved by injecting solutions of known concentrations, ranging from 0.05 to 5 mg /mL (R 2 ≤ 0.9998), of phenolic compounds as standards. Waters MassLynx software v.4.1 was used for data acquisition and processing. The sample measurement was done in triplicate, and expressed as mg/ 100 g (DW).

sec.title: 4.6. Statistical analysis
sec.p: All statistical analyses were performed using Statistica 13.1 (StatSoft Polska , Cracow, Poland ). Statistical significance of the differences between means was determined by testing the homogeneity of variance and normality of distribution, followed by ANOVA with Tukey’ s post hoc test. The significance was set at p < 0.05. The multidimensional analysis was carried out using the analysis of the main components (PCA). The data were scaled during pre-processing automatically.
Author contributions

Conceptualization, R.P; field research, R.P.; methodology, R.P, I.O., S.L., I.K., K.M., K.R.; formal analysis, R.P, I.O., S.L., I.K., K.M.; writingoriginal draft preparation, R.P, I.O., S.L., I.K., K.M., K.R.; writingreview and editing, R.P, I.O., S.L., I.K., K.M., K.R.; visualization, R.P, I. O. All authors approved the final version of the manuscript.

This research was supported by the West Pomeranian University of Technology of grants nr 518-07-014-3171-03/18.
Compliance with ethics requirements
This article does not contain any studies with human or animal subjects.

sec.title: Declaration of competing interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

sec.title: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.112844.
